bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the original.

div1.p:
In the Circuit Court
3d Judicial Circuit. November term AD 1836. St. Louis, to wit. Edward Gantt conplain of Thomas Baldwin of a plea of tresspass on the case. For that where as the said Edward Gartt heretofere, to writ, on the fifth day on January in the year one thousand with hundred & thirty six - at the county was St. Louis was lawfully possessed & of his own property of a certain mulatto man slave named Fanny of great value, to wit, of the value, of one thousand dollars. And being so possessed thereof he the said Edward Gantt afterward, to wit, on the day & year aforesaid at the county aforesaid, casually lost the said mulatto woman slave named Fanny out of his possession the same afternoon to wit, on the day & year last aforesaid of the county aforesaid cmae to the possession of the said Thomas Baldwin by finding. Yet the said Thomas Baldwin well knowing the said mulatto woman slave slave named Fanny to be the property if the said Edward Gantt & of right to belong & appertain to him hath not as yet delivered the said Edward Gantt although often requested so to do. & doth hitherto wholly refused so to do, afterward, to wit, on the day & year last aforesaid of the county aforesaid invited & disposed of the said mulatto woman slave named Fanny to his own use. To the damage of the said Edward Gantt of fifteen hundred dollars therefore he prays &
Gamble & Allen.
